docs.title: Welcome to DSGBench
docs.text: DSGBench is a novel strategic game benchmark designed to evaluate the performance of LLM-based agents in strategic planning, real-time decision making, adaptability, and multi-agent interactions. The benchmark encompasses six high-dynamics, complex strategy games, including StarCraft II, Civilization, Street Fighter III, and others. It provides fine-grained metrics for comprehensive evaluation, along with detailed decision trajectory analysis and trajectory datasets.

docs.title: What is DSGBench?
docs.text:
DSGBench focuses on testing the ability of LLM-based agents in the following aspects:

  • Decision-making: Making optimal choices in real-time or turn-based game scenarios.
  • Strategic Planning: Designing long-term strategies to achieve game objectives.
  • Adaptability: Adjusting strategies dynamically in response to environmental changes.
  • Multi-agent Interaction: Collaborating or competing with other agents in multi-agent games.

By supporting games like Starcraft II, Diplomacy, Werewolf, and more, DSGBench provides a comprehensive benchmark for evaluating LLM performance in decision-making and interaction-heavy tasks.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
1. Diverse Game Environments: DSGBench includes a variety of game environments, each offering unique challenges to LLM agents:
  2. Real-time strategy: Starcraft II
  3. Turn-based strategy: Civilization
  4. Social reasoning: Werewolf
  5. Negotiation and diplomacy: Diplomacy

  6. Strategic planning: Stratego

  7. Standardized Evaluation Metrics: A set of well-defined metrics to evaluate agents across decision-making accuracy, adaptability, and strategic interaction.

  8. Extensible Framework: Built on a modular codebase, DSGBench can be extended to support new games or integrate with other AI frameworks like OpenAI Gym.

  9. Open Source: DSGBench is fully open-source, enabling researchers to contribute, customize, and extend its functionality.

docs.text:
This documentation is divided into the following sections:

  • Environments: Detailed descriptions of the supported games, including rules, challenges, and required agent capabilities.

  • Evaluation and Capabilities: Overview of the evaluation metrics and the specific skills needed to succeed in DSGBench environments.

  • Code Framework: Technical guide for setting up the environment, interacting with LLM agents, and running experiments.

  • Experimental Setup: Guide to setting up and running experiments, including dataset preparation and result analysis.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
To get started with DSGBench, follow these steps:

  1. Clone the Repository: bash git clone https://github.com/your-repository/dsgbench.git cd dsgbench

  2. Install Dependencies: bash pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Game Detailed Description
docs.text: Starcraft II is a real-time strategy (RTS) game where players compete to gather resources, build bases, and control units to defeat opponents. The game requires players to make strategic decisions in real-time, balancing economy, army production, and combat. The game environment is dynamic and adversarial, making it a challenging scenario for LLM agents.

docs.title: Key Features:
docs.text:
• Resource Management: Players must gather minerals and vespene gas to fund their operations.
  • Base Building: Construct and upgrade structures to enable technology advancements.
  • Army Control: Train units and lead them in battles to destroy the opponent's base.
  • Fog of War: Players only have partial visibility of the map, requiring exploration and anticipation.

docs.title: Observation Space
docs.text:
The observation space in Starcraft II consists of various state information available to the agent, such as:

  1. Map View:
  2. A 2D grid of the map, with features like terrain, structures, and units.

  3. Data includes unit types, positions, health, and ownership (player or enemy).

  4. Resources:

  5. Current amounts of minerals and vespene gas.

  6. Available workers and resource nodes.

  7. Game State:

  8. Information about the player's base, including active structures, upgrades, and army composition.
  9. Limited visibility of enemy actions due to the fog of war.

docs.title: Data Format:
docs.text:
• Dimensions: A multi-channel 2D tensor representing the map state.
  • Types:
  • Numerical data for resources (e.g., integers for minerals and gas).
  • Categorical data for unit types and states (e.g., marine, zergling).

docs.title: Action Space
docs.text:
The action space in Starcraft II is diverse, including both high-level and low-level commands:

  1. Unit Commands:
  2. Move: Direct a unit or group of units to a specific location.
  3. Attack: Target an enemy unit or structure.

  4. Patrol: Command units to patrol between points.

  5. Base Management:

  6. Build: Construct buildings like barracks, factories, or supply depots.
  7. Train: Produce units (e.g., marines, tanks).

  8. Research: Upgrade units or unlock new technologies.

  9. Macro Actions:

  10. Expand: Build additional bases to increase resource gathering.
  11. Defend: Position units to defend against enemy attacks.
  12. Scout: Explore the map for enemy positions or resource nodes.

docs.title: Action Representation:
docs.text:
• Discrete: Select from a predefined set of actions (e.g., train_marine, build_barracks).
  • Continuous: Target specific positions on the map (e.g., move_to(x, y)).

docs.title: Eval Scenes
docs.text:
In Starcraft II, evaluation scenarios are designed to test different aspects of agent performance. Example evaluation scenes include:

  1. 1v1 Matches:
  2. Agent competes against another AI-controlled player.

  3. Tests strategic planning, resource management, and combat efficiency.

  4. Skirmish Mode:

  5. Focused on small-scale combat scenarios.

  6. Evaluates unit control and micro-management capabilities.

  7. Macro Management:

  8. Emphasizes long-term planning, base expansion, and resource optimization.

  9. Tests adaptability in prolonged games.

  10. Fog of War Scenarios:

  11. Agent operates under limited information.
  12. Evaluates scouting, prediction, and counter-strategy formulation.

docs.title: Metrics
docs.text:
The following metrics are used to evaluate agent performance in Starcraft II:

  1. Win Rate:

  2. Percentage of matches won against different levels of AI opponents.

  3. Resource Efficiency:

  4. Measures how efficiently the agent gathers and spends resources.

  5. Action Accuracy:

  6. Evaluates how effectively the agent executes actions (e.g., precise unit control).

  7. Adaptability:

  8. Assesses how quickly the agent adjusts strategies based on enemy actions or game changes.

  9. Combat Effectiveness:

  10. Ratio of units lost to units destroyed.

  11. Exploration Efficiency:

  12. Evaluates how well the agent uncovers the map and anticipates enemy strategies.

docs.title: Prompt Example
docs.text:
Here is an example prompt for initializing an LLM agent in the Starcraft II environment:

You are a commander in a real-time strategy game. Your goal is to defeat the enemy by gathering resources, building structures, and controlling your army. The map is partially visible, and you must anticipate enemy actions. 

- Current resources: 500 minerals, 200 gas
- Current units: 10 marines, 5 tanks
- Enemy sighted: Small zergling group approaching your base

What will you do next? Provide a detailed action plan.
